text:
<@UMVFWPZ36> Very nice. And I am also a big fan of Our World in Data. Please don't downplay the role of the UI in this project, that's what makes the difference with all the data repositories we have seen pop up recently, which nobody but specialists are willing to use. Making data accessible and explorable is hugely important these days.

What I'd like to know more about is how your spreadsheet-lie UI maps to tree notation. It's something I look at from time to time, and every time I have the impression of seeing something very important and not quite seeing why it matters. So a real-life example like this would be nice to see explained in more detail.

text: I think anyone teaching Rust should read this.

elements.text: I think anyone teaching Rust should read this.

text:
I love the concept of lenses (even not having used them before) and I wish your project much popularity. Some on FoC argue for schemaless databases (datalog etc), and I'm inclined to agree. Winning the popularity contest probably involves showing how to combine this with SQL databases, though.

You've basically made a DSL here, and my JSON-compatible language LES is designed for making DSLs. There isn't a TypeScript/JS version of it, but I am starting to ask people:

1. Have you heard of <http://loyc.net/les/|LES> or <http://loyc.net/loyc-trees/|Loyc trees>?
2. Would you have been interested in using them for your DSL? If not, why not?

elements.text:

You've basically made a DSL here, and my JSON-compatible language LES is designed for making DSLs. There isn't a TypeScript/JS version of it, but I am starting to ask people:

1. Have you heard of
LES
or
Loyc trees

?
2. Would you have been interested in using them for your DSL? If not, why not?

text: To make my question more precise: In <https://treenotation.org/#programsAreAlsoSpreadsheets>, you suggest a relation between tree notation and spreadsheets, but there is neither an explanation nor an example. There are of course many ways to encode a 2D array as a tree, but I have the impression that this is not what you have in mind. It looks like you want to do the opposite: use a 2D array interface to define general tree structures. But I see neither how to do this, nor why it is interesting.

elements.text: To make my question more precise: In

It looks like you want to do the opposite: use a 2D array interface to define general tree structures. But I see neither how to do this, nor why it is interesting.

text: Installed! Something I always wanted in tools like this was to indicate styles - bold, italic, `code` - in some way, e.g. pitch change, background hum. And some way to indicate punctuation, in a different way from words - like, on the screen I see `Enum.FooFlag | otherFlag` but it shouldn't be spoken quite like `enum foo flag other flag` or `enum dot foo flag vertical bar other flag`

code
- in some way, e.g. pitch change, background hum. And some way to indicate punctuation, in a different way from words - like, on the screen I see
Enum.FooFlag | otherFlag
but it shouldn't be spoken quite like
enum foo flag other flag
or
enum dot foo flag vertical bar other flag

text:
I suspect this is the sort of project where Loyc tools would be useful, because there's nothing really Python-specific about the goal here, and since it's Python, you can't (in general) be sure what the types are - so I guess that if you used a <http://loyc.net/loyc-trees/|Loyc tree> as the input to your prediction black box, it might work just as well on other languages.

But OTOH maybe you've just got a big AI model trained directly on source text and it doesn't actually know or care about the tree structure of the code?

Mind you an input module for Python doesn't actually exist, I'm just saying that _in principle_ it looks like a good fit... what do you think?

Loyc tree

as the input to your prediction black box, it might work just as well on other languages.

But OTOH maybe you've just got a big AI model trained directly on source text and it doesn't actually know or care about the tree structure of the code?

Mind you an input module for Python doesn't actually exist, I'm just saying that
in principle
it looks like a good fit... what do you think?

text: I don't have sound in the video. What's the concept here?

elements.text: I don't have sound in the video. What's the concept here?

text:
Thanks for the feedback Konrad!

I would say at this stage of the game the 2-D/3-D aspect is
important for the UI of programming. It's like WYSIWYG of
programming.

In Tree, scope has a semantic meaning but also a geometric
meaning—if things are down and to the right, they belong
together.

In Tree, there aren't infinite ways to write a list. There's
just one, and it's the way you would do it in the real
world: put items next to each other.

The languages follow constraints imposed by geometry. While
this may seem like it would limit creativity, in fact I've
found the opposite. By letting you focus on signal, and
removing all noise, you can focus on the semantics, and
really simplify your code to its essence.

There are also lots more you can do when you break out of
1-dimensional, linearly parsed languages. Tree Notation is a
subset of Grid Notation. There are other 2-D notations
out there.

An example might help. Would be easier to do a visual
but could try to put it into words. Imagine a project
wouldn't be a folder with a bunch of files, but instead one
file that you would open with a spreadsheet like IDE. and
edit like a canvas. What you'd normally put into files you
would instead drop an "anchor" in some cell in the sheet,
and start typing. That would be a root tree. And you could
have many of them throughout the canvas, instead of 1 file.
This is a good structure for languages for simulation. There
are some things like this, but none of them (AFAIK) have
ever made the layout and code isomorphic, and when you do
that you don't give up anything, and you make parsing and
tool building a lot easier.

text:
Now there are also implications for hardware, way down the
line, but at this stage it's about making things that ditch
a lot of complexity without sacrificing power, and present
the user with a code and interface that is a lot more
isomorphic to our brains which process info in a 2-D and 3-D
way.
